description: Workshop Drills - 1-3 minute guided exercises for Threshold Compass

drills.title: Box Breathing
drills.headline: Regulate your nervous system in 2 minutes
drills.tryThis: Inhale 4 seconds. Hold 4. Exhale 4. Hold 4. Repeat 6 times.
drills.whyItWorks: The equal intervals activate the parasympathetic nervous system, creating calm without sedation.
steps: Find a comfortable position
Breathe in through nose for 4 seconds
Hold at the top for 4 seconds
Exhale through mouth for 4 seconds
Hold at the bottom for 4 seconds
Repeat 6 cycles

drills.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
drills.headline: Return to the present moment through your senses
drills.tryThis: Name 5 things you see. 4 you hear. 3 you feel. 2 you smell. 1 you taste.
drills.whyItWorks: Engages the prefrontal cortex and interrupts rumination by forcing sensory attention.
steps: Look around. Name 5 things you can see.
Listen. Name 4 things you can hear.
Touch. Name 3 things you can feel.
Smell. Name 2 things you can smell.
Taste. Name 1 thing you can taste.

drills.title: Body Scan Express
drills.headline: Locate where you're holding tension in 90 seconds
drills.tryThis: Move attention from head to feet. Notice without judging. Mark what you find.
drills.whyItWorks: Awareness precedes release. You can't soften what you don't notice.
steps: Start at the top of your head
Notice any sensation. Don't judge it.
Move to your face, jaw, neck
Notice. Move on.
Shoulders, arms, hands
Chest, gut, lower back
Hips, legs, feet
Where did you find something?

drills.title: Intention Setting
drills.headline: Clarify direction before dosing
drills.tryThis: Answer three questions: What do I want more of? Less of? What could this teach me?
drills.whyItWorks: Direction > destination. A clear intention creates a filter for the experience.
steps: What do I want more of today?
What do I want less of today?
If this dose could teach me one thing, what would be most useful?

drills.title: Physiological Sigh
drills.headline: The fastest way to calm your nervous system
drills.tryThis: Double inhale through nose (full, then top off). Long exhale through mouth. Once is enough.
drills.whyItWorks: Discovered by Stanford researchers. Reinflates alveoli and triggers parasympathetic response faster than other breathing techniques.
steps: Inhale through nose until lungs feel full
Inhale again (top off) â€” you'll find there's more space
Long, slow exhale through mouth
One cycle is often enough

drills.title: Mindful Transition
drills.headline: Create a clean boundary between activities
drills.tryThis: Before switching tasks: stop, take 3 breaths, name what you're leaving and entering.
drills.whyItWorks: Transitions are where we lose ourselves. Marking them creates intentionality.
steps: Stop what you're doing completely
Take 3 slow breaths
Say to yourself: 'I'm leaving [activity]'
Say: 'I'm entering [next activity]'
Begin

drills.title: Peripheral Vision Reset
drills.headline: Shift from focused to open awareness
drills.tryThis: Pick a point straight ahead. Without moving eyes, expand awareness to periphery. Hold 60 seconds.
drills.whyItWorks: Focused vision activates alertness. Peripheral vision activates calm. This is a nervous system toggle.
steps: Find a spot directly in front of you to look at
Keep your eyes fixed on that spot
Without moving your eyes, notice what's at the edges of your vision
Expand that peripheral awareness as wide as possible
Hold for 60 seconds

drills.title: Shake It Off
drills.headline: Release stored tension through movement
drills.tryThis: Stand. Shake hands 30 seconds. Arms 30 seconds. Whole body 30 seconds. Stop. Notice.
drills.whyItWorks: Animals shake after stress to discharge nervous system activation. We suppress this instinct.
steps: Stand with soft knees
Shake just your hands for 30 seconds
Add your arms for 30 seconds
Shake your whole body for 30 seconds
Stop completely. Stand still. Notice what's different.

drills.title: Cold Snap
drills.headline: Acute stress for quick reset
drills.tryThis: 30 seconds of cold water on your face or hands. Focus only on the sensation.
drills.whyItWorks: Cold activates the dive reflex, slowing heart rate and increasing parasympathetic tone.
steps: Run the coldest water from your tap
Submerge your hands or splash your face
Hold for 30 seconds
Focus completely on the sensation of cold

drills.title: Object Meditation
drills.headline: Train attention with a single object
drills.tryThis: Pick up any small object. Explore it with full attention for 3 minutes. Every surface, every angle.
drills.whyItWorks: Single-point focus is a skill. Objects are easier than breath for beginners.
steps: Pick up any small object (phone, mug, stone)
Look at it as if you've never seen it before
Notice every detail: texture, weight, temperature
Turn it over. Find something new.
When your mind wanders, return to the object
